Cities: Skylines ‚Äì The True Successor to SimCity

Cities: Skylines stands tall as the spiritual successor to the classic SimCity franchise, carrying forward everything that made city-building games special while expanding the genre in amazing ways. From the moment you start laying down roads and zoning districts, it becomes clear just how much depth and freedom the game offers. The city-planning tools are intuitive yet powerful, letting you craft everything from cozy suburbs to sprawling megacities with incredible precision.

What really sets Cities: Skylines apart is the sheer level of detail. Traffic flow, public services, terrain, pollution, budgeting‚Äîevery system connects and reacts in a way that feels rewarding and believable. It‚Äôs the kind of game where you plan one small change and end up happily sinking hours into improving your city's overall design.

The only drawback is the downloadable content. There‚Äôs a lot of it, and while much of it adds meaningful features or new layers of complexity, the total cost can add up quickly. Still, the base game alone is packed with content, and players who dive into DLC will find even more ways to shape their perfect metropolis.

Overall, Cities: Skylines is a fantastic city-builder that fully captures the spirit of SimCity while evolving the formula into something deeper, richer, and endlessly engaging. A must-play for fans of the genre.

Amazing city builder. I have been playing the console version for years and didn't know what I was missing. It is extremely satisfying when a problem in your city has just been resolved, whether it be traffic jams, lack of services, or budget issues. Extensive modding support gives the game endless possibilities. The only thing I could possibly have to say is that simulating the lives of 300,000 little AI humans (only a problem in large cities) takes a lot of power. I understand that it is impossible to reduce the power used, but maybe the recommendation of 16GB RAM for Windows, 8 GB RAM for MacOS, and 8GB RAM for Steam Deck/Linux is a little bit misleading. Also, make sure you have NVIDIA¬Æ GeForce‚Ñ¢ RTX 30 series at least; you will be missing out on extremely detailed graphics otherwise. There are literally no other flaws to this extremely satisfying, award winning game, and I highly recommend this game to any fan of the city building genre

C:S was released in 2015 and I bought it on sale in 2016, played it a little in 2017 and came back to it in 2025. It's therefore quite hard to write a review playing the vanilla or base game only when there is such a multitude of DLC that has been released in the intervening years (there is also a sequel, released in 2023).

With that in mind, I can say I did enjoy my playthrough - I built a single city (and a small second version as it's necessary to unlock all the buildings) and obtained all the achievements possible in vanilla bar one (I just didn't have the energy to rebuild everything to get Happy Town). I don't intend to play further, but there's certainly scope to sink a lot of hours into this if you have the will and patience to master all the systems, get your head around traffic flow and invest a lot of money into the add-ons.

I personally think the best part of 30EUR for a game that is 10 years old is a bit steep - this is balanced by the strength of the modding community. The base systems are relatively simple to understand but the simplicity is also a source of some of the flaws - for example, I found watching buildings disappear and rebuild 'instantly' when you make a policy change really jarring and unrealistic.

It's a thumbs up if you want a long-term partnership, but this is not the partner for a short-term fling.

Cities: Skylines is a city-building simulation developed by Colossal Order and published by Paradox Interactive.

The gameplay focuses on designing and managing a modern city from the ground up. Players control zoning, road layouts, public services, taxation, and infrastructure while maintaining citizen happiness and economic stability. The systems interlock‚Äîtraffic flow, pollution, and resource management must all balance for sustainable growth.

The simulation depth is strong. Every citizen follows daily routines, traffic operates on a real pathfinding system, and city services respond dynamically to demand. Success requires efficiency and foresight rather than micromanagement.

Visually, the game presents a clean, realistic cityscape with adjustable camera angles and day‚Äìnight cycles. Buildings, vehicles, and landscapes are detailed enough for immersion while keeping performance stable across large city maps.

Sound design supports the relaxed tone. Ambient city noise, passing traffic, and background music blend smoothly, creating a calm management rhythm. Audio feedback from in-game events keeps the player aware of city conditions.

Modding support is one of its key strengths. The Steam Workshop integration allows players to add new assets, systems, and mechanics, turning Cities: Skylines into a nearly endless sandbox. Expansions and community mods have added seasons, transportation networks, and natural disasters.

Overall, Cities: Skylines stands as the most flexible and polished modern city builder. It rewards careful planning, creativity, and problem-solving while offering immense customization. It effectively replaced SimCity as the benchmark for the genre.
